## Unit 07: Directional Derivatives

Finally! This is critical for deep learning, as you know.

![00e17ad3.png](00e17ad3-kl2ssw8g.png)
!!! danger common mistakes:
Don't be a __numpty__: evaluate the derivative first, then set s=0.
Also, the unit vector __must always be normalized__!
!!!

And we can calculate these directional derivatives in terms of partial derivatives:

![c944292a.png](c944292a-kl2ssw8g.png)

---

![eae6b12b.png](eae6b12b-kl2ssw8g.png)

This is the money maker! Remember the property of the dot product:
$$ \vec{x} \cdot \vec{y}  = ||\vec{y}||||\vec{x}||\cos\Theta$$
Which is maximized when $\Theta = 0$. Alternatively, if we wanted to go down the slope, as is the case in gradient descent, we would choose $\Theta = \pi$, so $\cos{\Theta} = -1$ and the rate of change is just as great, but negative. Also, we could find the minimum rate of change by setting $\Theta = \frac{\pi}{2}$.

As we have an intuition for, the maximum rate of change is in a direction orthogonal to the level curve. This is formalized in the following theorem:

![af0e4b18.png](af0e4b18-kl2ssw8g.png)

We way orthogonal and not perpendicular because we can be working in more than 2 dimensions:

![10077c5a.png](10077c5a-kl2ssw8g.png)

So there's going to be a 3D surface, and the normal vector of that surface at a specific point is the Greatest Rate of Change vector.

So there's going to be a 3D surface, and the normal vector of that surface at a specific point is the Greatest Rate of Change vector.

![6a83fc9d.png](6a83fc9d-kl2ssw8g.png)

The equation of the tangent plane of a surface is given by:
$$f_x(a,b,c)(x-a) + f_y(a,b,c)(y -b) + f_z(a,b,c)(z-c) = 0$$
